text: Explains the standard terminology for different ways various works use tropes
Pigs with pneumonia
Flashbacks in a work are always black and white to represent a specific time period
The herd's health is good, so their feed intake exceeds the standard.
Eats loads and loads of food

The overall flock health is stable, the respiratory rate is low, and feed runs out early.
Nothing surprises me anymore
Someone's introductory moment that illustrates their abilities/personality/motives
Common stereotypes of the Nazis
pigs are often sick and have low body weight
Minors getting exposed to things which are usually not shown to children (like violence or sex)
Someone in ultimate authority over a work makes a genuine statement about an unexplained/ambiguous aspect of it
Bored with the ordinary place they live in
The feed intake and feed consumption in barn 1 are currently good.
A character's unusual Disproportionate Retribution rage trigger
A pest exterminator who takes their job very seriously
Severe (sometimes, capital) punishment for petty offenses (if at all)
A self-centered and ruthless social predator who preys on others for their own benefit
A character who seems to be the Final Boss, but is actually far from one
A plot where a location is taken over by bad guys and The Protagonist uses guerrilla tactics to stop them
An ending with a Plot Twist
The flock's good health leads to eating beyond the standard.
A Sibling Team composed of criminals
A gag parodies or reflects something from an actor's real-life history or whole previous role
A devious, insolent and self-assured character with an unjustly overinflated ego and delusions of grandeur
A villain who thinks they're the hero
A trope is hinted at, but not explicitly shown
Not just evil on large scales, but on small scales too
A character fights while in the nude
An ending that's more or less happy, but still has significant sad notes
In a group with Theme Naming, one name doesn't fit
